objdescid.compdate: c. 1780The date is based on stylistic considerations.

objinfo.leafsize: each approx. 7.5 x 9.5 cm., ovals.Butlin 84 speculates that these water colors may have been executed as rectangular compositions but later cut to their present oval shapes.
objinfo.medium: pen and ink and water color
objinfo.framelines: 1Fragmentary framing lines surround part of each object. The coloring extends beyond these lines on several objects.

provenance.name: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
provenance.note: Probably acquired directly from Blake by Thomas Butts; by inheritance to Thomas Butts, Jr., in 1845; sold Foster and Son auction, London, 29 June 1853, in lot 102 with Blake's water color, Abraham and Isaac (£1.3s. to the dealer H. G. Bohn); John Clark Strange by 1863; acquired at an unrecorded time (probably shortly before August 1883) by the dealer Bernard Quaritch; offered in Quaritch's catalogue 350 of August 1883, item 13842, with 26 other works by Blake from the Butts collection (£1200); the same group offered in Quaritch's catalogues of William Blake's Original Drawings, May 1885 and November 1886, first item (£1200); the same group offered in Quaritch's 1887 General Catalogue of Books, vol. 2, "Fine Arts: Supplementary Catalogue," item 13842 (£1200); the entire group sold 1890 to the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, probably at or slightly below the asking price of £1200.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In this illustration of Shakespeare's Romeo and Juliet, Juliet is depicted from the waist up in profile facing left. Contrary to the title, the scene is likely the moment before Juliet falls asleep after drinking a potion to make her appear dead to avoid an arranged marriage to Count Paris and thus remain true to Romeo. Juliet wears a loose garment, perhaps classically styled drapery, and her long curly hair cascades down both shoulders. She rests her bent right arm on an indistinguishable object (possibly a pillow) at left and holds a golden chalice in her left hand, which she raises to her lips with her bent right arm. With her head bent down and perhaps a tear visible below her eye, Juliet uses her right hand to raise the round object set inside the chalice to her parted lips. This object may be the vial described in Act 4, Scene 3: "My dismal scene I needs must act alone./Come, vial. [She takes out the vial.]" (20-21). In the final line of the scene, Juliet drinks the potion and collapses on her bed: "Romeo, Romeo, Romeo! Here's drink. I drink to/ thee. [She drinks and falls upon her bed within the curtains.]" (59-60).

component.illusobjdesc: Depicted from the waist up in profile facing left, Juliet wears a loose garment, perhaps classically styled drapery, and her long curly hair cascades down both shoulders. She rests her bent right arm on an indistinguishable object at left and holds a golden chalice or goblet in her left hand, which she raises to her lips with her bent right arm. With her head bent down and perhaps a tear visible below her eye, Juliet uses her right hand to raise the round object set inside the chalice-likely the vial of potion to make her appear dead-to her parted lips. This watercolor likely images the final line of the scene in which Juliet drinks the potion and collapses on her bed (which may be the indistinguishable object at left in this watercolor): "Romeo, Romeo, Romeo! Here's drink. I drink to/ thee. [She drinks and falls upon her bed within the curtains.]" (59-60).

In her raised left hand, Juliet holds a golden chalice or goblet. This cup appears to contain a round object, which may be the vial of potion Juliet intends to drink in order to appear dead. The object on which Juliet rests her right elbow may be a pillow or some other bedding.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Probably an illustration of Shakespeare's Henry IV, Part I, the scene depicts two male figures in an oval composition. The figure at left, who is older and bearded, faces forward and slightly right. His mouth may be open, suggesting he is speaking. He raises his right arm to touch the chest of the younger figure at right who is seen in profile facing left. This figure has short curly hair and wears a red garment with fashionable slashed sleeves. He rests his bent left arm on a table(?) in the lower right foreground and his right arm, which is bent upward, on the left shoulder of his companion. Both men wear round hats with a large plume. The older figure is probably Falstaff, a disgraced knight and constantly drunk comic character, while the more youthful figure likely represents Prince Hal, the rebellious heir to the British throne and son of King Henry IV. In the early acts of Henry IV, Part I, Falstaff acts as a sort of father figure to Prince Hal, and the pair spends much time together drinking and bantering in a pub, which may be the setting of this illustration. Their relationship sours, however, in Henry IV, Part II when Prince Hal overhears Falstaff falsely bragging and insulting Hal, who later turns Falstaff away from court after he ascends the throne as Henry V.

component.illusobjdesc: Probably an illustration of Shakespeare's Henry IV, Part I, the scene depicts two male figures in an oval composition. The figure at left, who is older with long hair and a beard, faces forward and slightly right. His mouth may be open, suggesting he is speaking. He raises his right arm and extends two fingers to touch the chest of the younger figure at right toward whom he also looks. Both men wear round hats with a large plume; the older figure's shirt includes a prominent collar and cuffs. The older figure is probably Falstaff, a disgraced knight and constantly drunk comic character who acts as a sort of father figure to Prince Hal, the younger figure, in the first acts of Henry IV, Part I.

component.characteristic: Most likely an illustration of Shakespeare's Henry IV, Part I, the scene depicts two male figures in an oval composition. The younger male figure at right has short curly hair and wears a red garment with fashionable slashed sleeves. He rests his bent left arm on a table(?) in the lower right foreground and his right arm, which is bent upward, on the left shoulder of his companion toward whom he also looks. Like his companion at left, he wears a round hat with a large plume. This figure is likely Prince Hal, the rebellious heir to the British throne and son of King Henry IV.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Othello and Desdemona, two of the main characters in Shakespeare’s play Othello, hold hands in a partial embrace in this illustration. Othello, the male figure at left, has short curly hair and dark skin. He appears to wear a cape(?) over metallic armor, which likely corresponds to his position as a general in the Venetian military. Although he faces forward, with head tilted he looks imploringly right toward his female companion Desdemona, whose hand he holds with his bent right arm. His left hand is visible, though sketchy, above Desdemona’s right hip, as if his arm is extended around her waist in a partial embrace. Desdemona looks toward Othello in profile facing left. She wears a long veil and gown, and this garment, along with her pale skin, contrasts sharply with Othello’s in color. In Act 5, Scene 2, he describes “that whiter skin of hers than snow,/ And smooth as monumental alabaster” (5). Her left arm is bent upward and held in front of her body by Othello. She extends her bent right arm across her chest with right fingers touching her left arm. The scene likely illustrates the exchange between the characters in Act 3, Scene 4, in which Othello, convinced Desdemona is adulterous, grabs her hand: “Give me your hand. [He takes her hand] This hand/ is moist, my lady.” (41-2) He continues: “Hot, hot, and moist. This hand of yours requires/A sequester from liberty, fasting and prayer,/ Much castigation, exercise devout;/ For here’s a young and sweating devil here/ That commonly rebels. ‘Tis a good hand/ A frank one.” (44-50). Unable to overcome his jealousy provoked by Iago’s lies, Othello smothers Desdemona on their bed and, upon learning the truth, kills himself in despair.

component.illusobjdesc: Othello, the male figure at left, has short curly hair and dark skin. He appears to wear a cape(?) over metallic armor, which likely corresponds to his position as a general in the Venetian military. Although he faces forward, with head tilted he looks imploringly right toward his female companion Desdemona, whose hand he holds with his bent right arm. His left hand is visible, though sketchy, above Desdemona’s right hip, as if his arm is extended around her waist in a partial embrace. The scene likely illustrates the exchange between the characters in Act 3, Scene 4, in which Othello, convinced Desdemona is adulterous, grabs her hand: “Give me your hand. [He takes her hand] This hand/ is moist, my lady.” (41-2) He continues: “Hot, hot, and moist. This hand of yours requires/A sequester from liberty, fasting and prayer,/ Much castigation, exercise devout;/ For here’s a young and sweating devil here/ That commonly rebels. ‘Tis a good hand/ A frank one.”

The female figure at right, Desdemona, looks toward Othello in profile facing left. She wears a veil over her long hair and a gown; this garment, along with her pale skin, contrasts sharply with Othello’s in color. In Act 5, Scene 2, he describes “that whiter skin of hers than snow,/ And smooth as monumental alabaster” (5). She wears an earring in her left ear. Her left arm is bent upward and held in front of her body by Othello. She extends her bent right arm across her chest with right fingers touching her left arm. The scene likely illustrates the exchange between the characters in Act 3, Scene 4, in which Othello, convinced Desdemona is adulterous, grabs her hand: “Give me your hand. [He takes her hand] This hand/ is moist, my lady.” (41-2)

desc.objtitle:
Cordelia and the Sleeping Lear,
object 4 (Butlin 84.4)

illustration.illusobjdesc: This image likely illustrates two characters from Shakespeare’s play King Lear: Lear’s daughter Cordelia and Lear himself, asleep on her lap. Cordelia, who has long hair and wears a gown, is depicted in profile facing right and down. She bends forward to look down over the body of her father. Her left arm is bent upward with her left hand touching or resting on her face; her left elbow may rest on Lear’s back. Cordelia may hold drapery in her left hand. Lear, who has white hair, a mustache, and beard, faces forward and sleeps with eyes closed, mouth perhaps slightly open. Only his head, shoulders, and right arm, which is bent upward beside his head, are visible in this illustration. He appears to wear drapery of some kind. This scene may illustrate the moment in Act 4, Scene 7 when Cordelia comes to care for the sleeping Lear, who upon waking, has overcome his previous state of madness. “Cordelia [kissing Lear]: O, my dear father, restoration hang/ Thy medicine on my lips, and let this kiss/ Repair those violent harms that my two sisters/ Have in thy reverence made.” (31-34).

component.illusobjdesc: The daughter of King Lear, Cordelia, who has long hair and wears a gown, is depicted in profile facing right and down. With right arm by her side, she bends forward to look down over the body of her father. Her left arm is bent upward with her left hand touching or resting on her face; her left elbow may rest on Lear’s back. Cordelia may hold drapery in her left hand. This scene may illustrate the moment in Act 4, Scene 7 when a sorrowful Cordelia comes to care for the sleeping Lear, who upon waking, overcomes his previous state of madness. “Cordelia [kissing Lear]: O, my dear father, restoration hang/ Thy medicine on my lips, and let this kiss/ Repair those violent harms that my two sisters/ Have in thy reverence made.” (31-34)

The overthrown and betrayed king of Britain, Lear, who has white hair, a mustache, and beard, faces forward and sleeps with eyes closed, mouth perhaps slightly open. Only his head, shoulders, and right arm, which is bent upward beside his head, are visible in this illustration. He appears to wear drapery of some kind. This scene may illustrate the moment in Act 4, Scene 7 when Cordelia comes to care for the sleeping Lear, who upon waking, has overcome his previous state of madness. “Cordelia [kissing Lear]: O, my dear father, restoration hang/ Thy medicine on my lips, and let this kiss/ Repair those violent harms that my two sisters/ Have in thy reverence made.” (31-34).

illustration.illusobjdesc: An older male figure with his hunched back toward the viewer twists sharply to face forward and slightly right. He has a long beard, and his white hair blows to the right as if lifted by the wind. He wears dark drapery and holds a downward-pointed sword with his raised left hand, which is clenched in a fist around the hilt. His right arm appears to be bent and perhaps wrapped around his body. A cloudy sky appears in the background. This figure is likely Lear from Shakespeare’s play King Lear perhaps during the raging storm in Act 3, Scene 2, in which he declares: “Blow winds, and crack your cheeks! Rage, blow!/ You cataracts and hurricanoes, spout/ Till you have drenched our steeples, the cocks./ You sulph’rous and thought-executing fires,/ Vaunt-couriers of oak-cleaving thunderbolts,/ Singe my white head. And thou, all-shaking thunder,/ Strike flat the thick rotundity o’ th’ world./ Crack nature’s molds, all germens spill at once/ That makes ingrateful man” (1-11).

component.illusobjdesc: An older male figure with his hunched back toward the viewer twists sharply to face forward and slightly right. He has a long beard, and his white hair blows to the right as if lifted by the wind. He wears dark drapery and holds a downward-pointed sword with his raised left hand, which is clenched in a fist around the hilt. His right arm appears to be bent and perhaps wrapped around his body. A cloudy sky appears in the background. This figure is likely Lear from Shakespeare’s play King Lear perhaps during the raging storm in Act 3, Scene 2.
The male figure in this image, likely Lear from Shakespeare’s play King Lear, holds the hilt of a downward-pointed sword in his left hand near the right side of the image.
A dark sky with clouds is visible behind the figure in this image, and a strong wind appears to blow his hair to the right. The scene likely illustrates the raging storm in Act 3, Scene 2.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Two figures look toward each other as the woman at left touches the arm of the male figure at right. Depicted in profile facing right, the female figure has her long hair arranged in a bun and wears a gown(?) with a belt and a shawl over her shoulders. She extends her raised right arm to the right and points with her index finger. Her bent left arm rests on the right forearm of her companion, who faces forward but turns slightly left to look toward her. The male figure has short curly hair and a bushy beard and mustache. His mouth may be open, perhaps suggesting he is speaking. He wears long-sleeved armor. His right arm is bent and held in front of his chest; he may hold an indistinguishable object in his right hand. His left arm is bent and raised near his throat. He may touch his chest with his raised left hand. This pair of figures is likely Macbeth and his wife Lady Macbeth from Shakespeare's play Macbeth, perhaps depicted during one of their many conversations about plotting to gain greater political power.

component.illusobjdesc: Two figures look toward each other as the woman at left touches the arm of the male figure at right. Depicted in profile facing right, the female figure has her long hair arranged in a bun and wears a gown(?) with a belt and a shawl or drapery over her shoulders. She extends her raised right arm to the right and points with her index finger. Her bent left arm rests on the right forearm of her companion. This pair of figures is likely Macbeth and his wife Lady Macbeth from Shakespeare's play Macbeth, perhaps depicted during one of their many conversations about plotting to gain greater political power.

Two figures look toward each other as the woman at left touches the arm of the male figure at right. Facing forward and slightly left, the male figure has short curly hair and a bushy beard and mustache. His mouth may be open, perhaps suggesting he is speaking. He wears long-sleeved armor. His right arm is bent and held in front of his chest; he may hold an indistinguishable object in his right hand. His left arm is bent and raised near his throat. He may touch his chest with his raised left hand. This pair of figures is likely Macbeth and his wife Lady Macbeth from Shakespeare's play Macbeth, perhaps depicted during one of their many conversations about plotting to gain greater political power.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Two figures—a young woman at left and an older man at right—face each other in this illustration. The male figure, visible in profile facing left, has white hair and a long beard. His mouth appears to be open, suggesting he is speaking. He wears a long-sleeved garment (perhaps a gown?) with blue drapery (possibly a cloak) around his left shoulder and right arm, which is bent at the elbow and rests on an indistinguishable object in the lower left foreground. He points to the right with his right index finger. The female figure at left faces forward and slightly right to look toward her male companion. She has long hair and wears a veil and what may be a gown(?). She rests her right elbow on an indistinguishable object in the lower left foreground and bends her arm upward to grasp her hair with her right hand. These figures may be Prospero and Miranda, the exiled father and daughter duo from Shakespeare’s play The Tempest.

component.illusobjdesc: Two figures—a young woman at left and an older man at right—face each other in this illustration. The male figure, visible in profile facing left, has white hair and a long beard. His mouth appears to be open, suggesting he is speaking. He wears a long-sleeved garment (perhaps a gown?) with blue drapery (possibly a cloak) around his left shoulder and right arm, which is bent at the elbow and rests on an indistinguishable object in the lower left foreground. He points to the right with his right index finger. This figure may be Prospero, the former Duke of Milan turned magician, from Shakespeare’s play The Tempest depicted with his daughter Miranda.

Two figures—a young woman at left and an older man at right—face each other in this illustration. The female figure at left faces forward and slightly right to look toward her male companion. She has long hair and wears a veil and what may be a gown(?). She rests her right elbow on an indistinguishable object in the lower left foreground and bends her arm upward to grasp or pull her hair with her right hand. This figure may be Miranda, the daughter of Prospero, the former Duke of Milan turned magician, from Shakespeare’s play The Tempest.
